text: Bottle, picked up in La Crescent. POurs clear orange, medium off-white head, dissipates fairly slowly, good lacing. Aroma is grass, very herbal, juniper, lemon. Flavor is medium sweet, light bitter, honey, herbal, juniper. Medium body, high carbonation. Interesting, not sure if that means good or not.

This is a corked, 750 mL curvaceous bottle supplied by Stine; and received only moments ago via timely postal carrier. The Rollingstone city council (Rollingstone, MN) should invite The Rolling Stones to play at Legends Sports & Bar. Actually, the name for this seriously small city of thiers isnt THAT funny. Its unique. Ill leave it at that.  The pour is an unclean (not due to an infection; cloudy) murky carrot orange, producing one of the slimmest of light ale heads Ive seen in a very long while: razor-thin fingernail-sized off-white presentation: this carbonative necessity stood blandly for approximately 4 seconds before shriveling up and disappearing from the surface area almost entirely.  It has curious aromas of stale lemonade, banana skins, crushed coriander, a touch of spelt flour, cotton, and the briefest hints of underripe juniper. Startlingly diminutive for the amount of yeast detected. The flavors are practically identical to its aromas, with the addition of bubblegum, caramel, and sour grass, Strangely sweet: kind of weirdly honeyed, experienced most prominently at swallow. This candied irritant was like if you, for whatever reason, decided to microwave clover honey for a half hour, then scooping it up and dumping it in an iced herbal tea.  Oh, and I should probably also mention that this baby is hot as hell and doesnt hide it (if you catch my drift). I felt unusually smashed after just three swigs. I mean, if the ass-kicking acohol content can be attractively concealed, then go for it, but this Saison-base traditional may need some pointers on this, sorry.  Papery, thin mouthfeel. Farm Breweries (I.E. breweries that either own a farm or brew beers on the premises if farms) are not always guaranteed to give you that oh-so desired authentic taste and fluffiness from their farmhouse ales. Ive learned this the hard way.

Bottle... Clear amber pour with a small creamy, white head. Fantastic retention. The nose is restrained, but Im able to pull light notes of juniper and honey from my glass. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and laid-back carbonation. Tastes like a honey and sorghum beer. Theres a trace of molasses here. Trends sweet, but not cloying. An odd and interesting beer. Pretty good. Bottle courtesy of BVery!
On tap at ABR - this was a Bourbon Barrel Aged version. A hot saison style that was a good canvas for the boubon to come through.
Fliptop 750 from Guerde. Pours beautiful copper with a creamy beige head. Spicy berry and mild roast caramel aroma. Med body. Flavor is very lightly fructose with bitter berry for balance. Very nice.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours orange blonde with an attractive beige head and a strange, probably juniper, aroma. There is a sweet malt flavor with some honey and a bittering juniper influence.

A nice big flip-top bottle shared by my friend at the First Kinki Beer Tasting. I like what Olvade Farms is doing, cool old style beers that are right up my alley. A cloudy honey gold pour pungeant, raisin fruity aroma on a medium body. The flavor was honey comb, sweet, fruity, musty & spicy. As noted by people at the tasting "A slice of awesomeness".

Bottle thanks to Skyview:   Darker straw, candied orange hue, thin sudsy white head, spotty lacing.   Sweet candied melon on the nose, a little musty but in a sweet way.   A bit bready too.   A little mealy and straw like, strong straw yet sweet, on the tongue.   A bit flat, gushed when opened but carbonation is light.   Otherwise moderate body and mouthfeel.   Mealy finish, slightly sweet, bready, with a slight tame gooseberry flavor.   Interesting, wished it were a bit more tart or sour to balance out the mealieness.   Interesting to say the least.   Some melon balls in there too.
Bottle sampled at RBSG. From notes. Honey, apples and a little juniper. Another great beer from this brewery.

Well, you just cant mistake the juniper here. Its front and center and in proportions enough to please James Bond or other gin & tonic drinkers. But there is a delicate balance here that is really tremendous. This beer screams out with authenticity, as if a farmer brewed it to an old recipe--theres an earthy, natural, balanced flavor to complement the juniper. Really good. (bottle, 2013 Ale Jail festival, St. Paul, MN)

Nice banana & clove aroma. Big fluffy long lasting amber head. Beautiful and refreshing, but rich. Malt flavor leans toward Pilsner and maybe a hint of Munich malts. Slightly under-attenuated, but not quite cloyingly sweet. More alcohol than you feel upon drinking it. Mediocre finish with just a bit of dryness.
Belgian yeast big sweetness. Looks Is this a farmhouse or what. Big head. With the Juniper, odd and interesting. Ok drinkability.A little colour and this is a traditional?
Copper pour, thumb of head. Musty aroma. Spicy. Juniper in the taste, sugary, yeasty. Medium body. No booze detected.

Bottle - good size foamy head, beautiful medium copper color, sweet berry aroma and flavor - but not overly sweet or overly berry, Belg yeasty notes in the background as well - different and good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Poured a golden / copper color with an averaged sized head. Berries, bready, citrus, and spices, Sweeter and and Im guessing its the Juniper berries that were stronger in the tastes.

750mL bottle, 2013 vintage. Poured orangey-golden with a thick, dense, well-retained off-white head.. looked great! The aroma picked up bitter orange peel, strawberry, juniper, and a touch of rye over honey and sweet bready malts.. big and warm on the back of the nose.. maybe a touch heavy-handed, but it was very interesting. The flavor found honey and sweeter bready notes at the core, with lightly-tart juniper berries, toasted rye, a bit of oak, and peppery notes around.. finished very dry with lightly sour berries and peppered oak over honey. Medium-bodied and well-carbonated.. the berries kept it tangy and engaging.. a little busy at times, but very interesting and tasty.

Bottle. Pours a hazy copper color with white head. Barnyard, yeasty, wet blanket aromas. Barnyard, yeasty, juniper, malty flavors. Pretty cool beer. I wasn’t expecting this to be as good as it was.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. A sweet nose of honey, yeast and apples. A smooth very sweet flavor with honey, juniper, some caramel like sweetness. Yeasty and dry. Very interesting and good.

Very deep gold, clear, off-white bead. Aroma of grainy-sweet malt, peppery phenols, floral and perfumy notes, and definite juniper. Flavor of rose pedals. honey-sweet malt, spicy phenols, big juniper. Interesting but on the sweet side. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Pours a hazy copper color with white head.  Barnyard, yeasty, wet blanket aromas.  Barnyard, yeasty, juniper, malty flavors.  Pretty cool beer.  I wasnt expecting this to be as good as it was.

Bottle in KC thanks to jcnielsen. Thanks Justin! Pours a fairly murky, dark orange appearance with a full, cream colored head. Fairly floral, orange blossom, sage, yeasty, tangy aroma. Sort of chewy/bready yeasty, tangy orange fruity, big juniper, lightly tart flavor. Sort of like a Sahti. Wow, thats a pretty fucken cool brew.
At Stillwater Brewers Bazaar 7, Pale straw pour, minimal head. Berry, floral scent and taste, not my style.
Sweet nose. Honey and spice predominant on palate. Some alcohol burn and fairly sweet. Big carbonation. Nice summer beer
Bottle. Pours an unclear dark orange with tons of honey on the nose. Flavor  honey and spices, quite sweet. Good beer, not my favorite of theirs though.

Bottle thanks to khoffman43. Pours reddish amber. Nose and taste of alcohol soaked fruits, juniper, peach pit, honey bread, hay, yeast and dark fruit. Medium body. A little bit of alcohol in the finish. A touch over sweet.

Cloudy brownish orange with massive peach-white head. Aroma is strongly breadlike, with apricot, cinnamon, hay, and honey notes. Taste is very sweet. The body is heavier, but the active carbonation keeps it from having a syrupy feel. The swingtop made a rather loud "pop" each time openned.

While moving this one, the poorly constructed cap broke so I had to drink it up.  Amber with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of yeast, grassy and earthy hops, fruit and bready notes.  Taste is sweet and earthy with juniper, fruit, alcohol and malt.  Sweet to the point of cloying.

Name: Brynhidrs Gift
Date: October 28, 2012
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: cloudy orange, fine off white head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet fruity aroma, touch of spicyness, light mustyness
Flavor: sweet fruity flavor, balancing spicyness, peach and apricot
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4

750ml swing top courtesy of theisti, thanks Tim.  Spicey honey, herbal, slightly floral, hint of banana and a touch of dough.  Great tight carbonation with a medium to full feel.  Doughy honey, spicey banana yeast notes, slight hint of juniper...more just a general herbal character.  Nice honey finish, solid stuff.

Honey caramel juniper herbal notes a little airy mineral notes. Pours golden orange amber nice head and lace.  Flavors pf honey and juniper caramel and herbal notes. Sweet sugary finish nice carbonated finish. Interesting.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of herbs, nuts, juniper, toasted grain, and honey.  Flavor of honey, grain, nuts, and earthiness.
750 flip top thanks to khoffman43. Big yeasty saison with spicy nature and good fruity taste due to junipers. Very interesting take on the saison. Enjoyable.
750. Not much aroma. Really complea, fruity beer. Creamy, yeasty . Very nice.

Cloudy orange color with a large head.  Strong yeasty aroma with some light spiciness.  Sweet wheat flavor.  Some hay and sugary character.  Not distinctly spiced.  Its a little like a sweet saison, minus the funk of the yeast, which doesnt make it a bad beer, just unexpected.

Swing top bottle, and a big pop when it was opened. Light orange oclor and a lacing head that sticks around until the end of the beer. The aroma has Belgian yeast and sugar.  As others have said, it is quite sweet in the flavor, with more yeast here as well.  Some spice, as well as what I taste as pine. Thick, rich palate. Much sweeter than expected.  I anticipated a dry sahti.  It is still a good beer.

750 ml fliptop courtesy of Derek. Thanks, bud! Pours a richer amber copper hue, firm haze grows with a cakey offwhite head atop. Big overall, firm lacing, sticks around well. Aromas are lemons, touches of grapefruit, florals, and firm piney influence. Gentle pear and apple sweetness grow, firm fruit, dryness and yeast come into play quickly. Initial is medium bodied, firm apple and estery fruit, touches of biscuit, toast, and gentle carmelization. Touches of peanuts, gentle yeast, touches of pine. An odd brew. Touches of dryness, jabs of yeast, and sweet malts into the finish. Hmmmm. I get what its going for... that Sahti feel.. I guess its just not a style I enjoy.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy gold with an amber hue and a gray head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has some honey with a decent amount of hay and a backing sweet grain. Flavor has a light fruit note with a good amount of hay with a sweet grain finish.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle at St. Paul Summer Beer Fest. Slightly hazy orange pour with an off-white head. Malty, fruity, herbal, and juniper. Nice brew.

Thanks to PaulUnwin for sharing this one around.  Cheers, Paul!  Pours a hazy yellow-amber with a white head.  Nose is sweet malt, light fruit, and some herb and spice notes.  Flavor is similar with the sweetness and the herbal notes melding well.  This was an enjoyable beer with great balance.  Medium in body and lingering sweetness in the finish.

@markwise Birthday-palooza-a-go-go Gathering-thanks PaulUnwin-750 bottle-pours hazy gold with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is berry, herbal, sweet medium malt.  Taste is berry, herbal, sweet medium malt-caramel.  Easy.

Flip Top bottle shared by PaulUnwin at Markwises Bday Bash, poured a light amber color, aromas of banana, spice, light juniper, and some honey.  Flavors are the same as aroma, something different on the aftertaste, not juniper, interesting overall though.

Flip top 2012 bottle through trade. Pour has a dark amber color with an off white head. Aroma has a good hit of juniper berry, honey, caramel, grains, and an overall sweet tone. Mouth feel is medium and the carbonation is medium high. Flavor has loads of sweetness, Belgian like, spicy juniper berry, yeast, and some rye. Just too much sweetness that dominates the beer.

Bottle.  Slightly hazy dark tan/orange pour, decent amount of carbonation and a sweet banana and honey nose.  Flavor is very sweet honey and spices, some nice rye coming through and warming on the aftertaste.  A bit too sweet in my opinion, but still worth picking up.

Just picked this brand new beer up from Zipps. Joe Pond has surely proven his brewing capabilities by now, I hope this one holds up to the standard that hes set for himself. Poured from 750ml swing top to tulip:

Pours a deep, hazy pear/gold with a swelling soft white head. Precise lacing and moderate, consistent beading. Really a gorgeous beer to look at.

Youll know by the nose that he wasnt stingy with the juniper. Bright juniper notes supported with big yeast, clove, banana, some nutty bits, spicy cereal malts. Lovely, fresh, complex.

The nose gave me high hopes that the flavors surpassed. Id have to guess that Aurochs Horn is the base beer here. It seems like the juniper really beefs up the beer. Some bitter, malty caramel are thrown into the mix. Sweet bread. Sort of a tangy finish thats hard to dissect.

Overall, this is exactly what I was hoping for. This guy really knows how to brew great beer. I hope he does big things but, at the same time, I wish he would just keep doing his thing because he really has a knack for this.

Pick up single 750 corked and caged bomber from Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, MN. Pours a hazy orange amber colored brew with a thick beige head that has some excellent retention and lacing. Aroma of Belgian-style yeast, a hint of peaches, honey, some light vanilla, and Asian lychee. Taste is full bodied, soft carbonation with flavors of Belgian yeast, peaches, a hint of apricot, banana and honey. Finish is quite sweet, somewhat oily with an aftertaste of banana/yeast peaches and honey. Juniper berries are hidden in the extra body and yeast flavors.

Hazy copper pour with a nice bubbly head.
Aroma is herbal and toasted malt.
Flavour is sweet, honey and caramel. Herbal juniper quality towards the finish. Pretty sweet

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had this at a beerfest, and now from the bottle.  Juniper is upfront and good aroma.  Taste is good and smooth.  A nice pair with a light body cigar.

Nice nose, quite sweet in taste. The nose is a little nicer than the taste, which is just overwhelmed by honey. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, dark orange, yellow with a slight white head, aroma brought notes of honey, juniper with hints of mint, berry, some slight vanilla, touch of grape, pear.  Taste is a mix of grass, honey, vanilla, some berry, sweet mint and more honey notes, touch of pear, white grape, finishing fairly sweet.

(bottle) Pours a very, very hazy orange color with a large off-white head that possesses a shaving cream like consistency and retains very well.  The aroma has up front some graham cracker, but the juniper shines through as well.  Further warming opens up some fruit character such as pineapple and canned lychee.  Peaches as well and further on some funk and earthiness makes an appearance.  Pretty complex scent, but everything is very dialed down.  The flavor is reminiscent of canned yellow peach juice, light pineapple juice, and banana, which quickly morphs to a faintly herbal and a dry, crackery finish.  Really digging the flavor.  Mouthfeel is a little thicker than expected, and carbonation is soft.  Overall this is a solid beer, but didnt quite meet my expectations.  It appears there are some funky elements lurking within this beer, so I may need to purchase another for aging.

Bottle. Pours hazy amber with a large foamy khaki head that fades to a film. Aroma is fruity bread and malt with a hint of tartness. Taste is again sweet with fruit like berries and malty with notes of honey and bread. Palate is fizzy and slick with a chalky drying finish. More tartness and this could be special!
